channel.title: From Python to?
channel.description:
Provided one already somewhat knows Python, which language should one go for next?
As far as I have understood, universities tend to be C++/Java/C elitists, so I do feel I should get started on something else than Python before that.
I would rather not touch Java, so I suppose C++/C/something else, but anyone have any suggestions?

item.title: From Python to?
item.dc:creator: @cruel cruel
item.description:
@cruel wrote:

I suggest you jump right into C++ with GNU autotools build environment. Then try configuring some sort of mingw gcc cross-compiling toolchain and, with the help of gtk+ and maybe glade for XML UI, create a nice cross-platform application with a GUI. Or you could just stick to your faggot python/java nonsense that makes it too easy.

loljk i use python like every day

Read full topic

item.title: From Python to?
item.dc:creator: @SETO SETO
item.description:
@SETO wrote:

though native C, and C++ speaker, i love python over java, python is just like java with simpler syntax [before i get sued, what i mean is writing, and nothing to do with capability].

though currently i am using Java, for network simulation

Read full topic

item.title: From Python to?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

it’s different from modern OO languages. sure there’s structs in C, but they’re not the same as classes. at least with C++ you’ve got some common ground with java and even python to some extent. (no, i am not advocating C and C++ are two different things, of course you use C code in C++); my point is that from a background of wanky OO, C++ will be less awkward than C.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Reddit is almost entirely Python

Youtube is almost entirely Python as well, according to Guido.

Youtube? Reddit? Eve Online? A vast portion of the Linux desktops?[/quote]

By huge I didn’t mean usage.

item.dc:creator: @Yume Yume

@Yume wrote:

I am kind of still leaning towards C++ over Java; I have not really shared a lot of the stuff I have made as it has thus far mostly been for personal use, so I do not currently see distribution as an issue…

Read full topic

item.title: From Python to?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

C++'s libraries are non-existent compared to Java’s standard libraries. However, you can use the Boost libraries that bring them almost up to par with Java’s standard library.

[quote=“Yume, post:15, topic:430375”][quote author=Rix_ link=topic=533058.msg3897060#msg3897060 date=1327404200]
If I were you, I’d start with C++ before going on to Java. This is a recent picture of me writing things in C++ after I’ve learned Java.


[/quote]

Does Java have any particular uses that Python/C++ would not have?[/quote]

Web Applets are the main thing that Java has over the other two. Also more people have the JVM installed than the python runtime, which you would generally have to bundle with your program on platforms like windows. Lastly, with C++ you have to be very careful with, and sometimes even write the same method twice to make it work the same under multiple compilers and/or platforms, then you have to distribute multiple binaries, one for each platfrom. With Java all of that is taken care of for you, and you can ‘compile once, run everywhere’.

Read full topic

item.title: From Python to?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Yume, post:17, topic:430375”][quote author=t4 link=topic=533058.msg3897151#msg3897151 date=1327417774]

If I were you, I’d start with C++ before going on to Java. This is a recent picture of me writing things in C++ after I’ve learned Java.

http://i.imgur.com/tJqrf.jpg

Does Java have any particular uses that Python/C++ would not have?

For one, C++ is a fully compiled languages. The Java default libraries are far more offering than that of Python and C++. Also, no one really writes anything huge in Python - it’s mostly used to plugins.
[/quote]

I disagree on the nobody using Python for anything huge - It is used by some (though probably less than more popular languages) for scientific purposes, it is a more or less decent replacement for PHP (django), and it is used by many larger companies (For instance Google (they use several languages)).

Putting aside Javas libraries, how are C++’ libraries compared to those of Python?[/quote]
i guess what i meant as huge was it being used as a backbone.

STL: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Standard_Template_Library

Read full topic

item.title: From Python to?
item.dc:creator: @Yume Yume
item.description:
@Yume wrote:

[quote=“Yume, post:15, topic:430375”][quote author=Rix_ link=topic=533058.msg3897060#msg3897060 date=1327404200]
If I were you, I’d start with C++ before going on to Java. This is a recent picture of me writing things in C++ after I’ve learned Java.


[/quote]

Does Java have any particular uses that Python/C++ would not have?[/quote]
For one, C++ is a fully compiled languages. The Java default libraries are far more offering than that of Python and C++. Also, no one really writes anything huge in Python - it’s mostly used to plugins.
[/quote]

I disagree on the nobody using Python for anything huge - It is used by some (though probably less than more popular languages) for scientific purposes, it is a more or less decent replacement for PHP (django), and it is used by many larger companies (For instance Google (they use several languages)).

Putting aside Javas libraries, how are C++’ libraries compared to those of Python?

Read full topic
